dc:description:
Primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) is a clinically and genetically heterogeneous group of diseases resulting from variants in genes involved in the transport, assembly, and function of motile cilia (PMID 33304404). The HYDIN gene was first reported to cause PCD5 in humans in 2012 (PMID 23022101). Major parts of the gene are duplicated in the HYDIN2 pseudogene which might confound genetic diagnosis. Ciliary defects of the respiratory epithelium in the reported patients result in otitis media, sinusitis, recurrent chest infection and progressive airway destruction. Male infertility due to dysfunctional sperm tails is also reported (PMID 23022101). Absence of the situs inversus phenotype characteristic of other forms of PCD reflects the underlying defect in central pair (CP) apparatus, which is considered irrelevant to the nodal cilium that establishes the left-right body asymmetry (PMID 31545650). Deficiency of the CP-apparatus-associated protein HYDIN results in lack of the C2b projection of the central pair with reduced beating amplitudes of respiratory cilia and stiff sperm flagella (PMID 23022101).
Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found the molecular mechanism and autosomal recessive mode of inheritance to be consistent among unrelated patients, while the phenotypic variability among them appeared to represent a spectrum of disease rather than separate disease entities. Therefore, the asserted disease associated with HYDIN variants, primary ciliary dyskinesia 5 (MONDO:0012088), was curated as a single entity.
Ten splice site, nonsense and frameshift variants were reported in 5 publications (PMIDS 23022101, 23849777, 31089940, 31545650, 26139845). The disease consistently segregates in 1 German and 3  Faroe Islander families, and provides a scorable genetic evidence for segregation analysis of the autosomal recessive disease (PMID 23022101).
Experimental evidence also supports this gene disease association. HYDIN expression in ciliated epithelial tissues relevant to PCD was identified in multiple papers (PMIDs 23715323, 12719380).  The biochemical function of HYDIN protein in the axonemal central pair and its functional alteration in patient cells are consistent with a critical role in motile cilia structure and function (PMID 23022101). Abnormal ciliary structure and function were also evident in Hydin mutant mice (PMID 18250199). Similarly, Hydin knockdown causes flagellar paralysis in Chlamydomonas (PMID 17296796).
In summary, HYDIN is definitively associated with autosomal recessive primary ciliary dyskinesia 5. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both research and diagnostic settings and has been upheld over time. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on February 10th, 2022 (SOP Version 8).

evidence.dc:description: Score was reduced to avoid double scoring for similar evidence. (Findings match scored human expression evidence PMID: 23715323)
Hydin mRNA is detected in the bronchial  lining of the lung , spermatocytes within the semeniferous tubules of the testis  and the lining of the oviduct .
evidence.rdfs:label: Analysis of Hydin expression in adult FVB/N mice

evidence.dc:description: Normal expression of HYDIN has been detected in testis, fallopian tubes(relevant to infertility) and brain tissue (hydrocephalus may occur on rare occasion in individuals with PCD and may reflect dysfunctional ependymal cilia (genereviews, primary ciliary dyskinesia). Because the lung is comprised of array of cell types, especially, alveolar macrophages and type II alveolar cells, that might be related to the phenotypes described (recurrent chest infections and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome), we avoided scoring bulk tissue evidence. We scored single cell expression of HYDIN gene in epithelial ciliated lung cells which explain defective mucociliary function and recurrent respiratory tract infection phenotype in PCD5 patients.

To establish a resource database and associated tissue bank to study the relationship between genetic variation and gene expression in human tissues, donors of any racial and ethnic group and sex who are age 21–70 in whom biospecimen collection can start within 24 hours of death were eligible. Medical exclusionary criteria were: human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection or high-risk behaviors, viral hepatitis, metastatic cancer, chemotherapy or radiation therapy for any condition within the past 2 years, whole blood transfusion in past 48 hours, or body mass index ≥ 35 or ≤18.5. Each BSS collects, where feasible, aliquots from many pre-designated tissue sites and organs, including the brain of deceased donors who were not on a ventilator for the 24 hours prior to death. 
A dedicated team of pathologists reviews slides from all tissue specimens to verify the organ source and to characterize both general pathological characteristics, such as autolysis, as well as organ-specific pathological states and inflammation. 
Normal expression of HYDIN has been detected in testis, fallopian tubes and brain tissue. Single cell snRNA-seq pilot detected HYDIN expression in 800 out of 992 (80.65%) ciliated epithelial lung cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: The Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) project

evidence.dc:description: Proteomic analysis is performed on a model organism not on human cilia.

Cilia and flagella, are essentially identical organelles and hereafter referred to interchangeably. Homologues of HYDIN gene detected in flagellar proteome, along with other numerous proteins associated with diseases such as cystic kidney disease, male sterility, indicates its role in ciliary structure and/or function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Proteomic analysis of a eukaryotic cilium

evidence.dc:description: All HYDIN mutant cells examined showed no SPEF2 signal (lack of SPEF2 by IF analyses). All affected individuals had clinical features consistent with PCD . However, SPEF2 mutations that also result in absent axonemal SPEF2 have been associated with male infertility but have not previously been identified to cause PCD. So, we downscored for lack of evidence of specificity of the biochemical evidence.  Also, HSVM has not been utilized to confirm the abnormal ciliary motility in patient cells.

While healthy control cell exhibit SPEF2 along the axoneme, patient respiratory epithelial cells showed reduced or absent SPEF2, lack of central pair axonemal assembly and  stiff motility are the main basis for lack of mucociliary clearance
evidence.rdfs:label: HYDIN-Mutant Cilia Lack SPEF2 (CP associated Protein).

evidence.dc:description: Colocalization of HYDIN in CP illustrated in the flagellum of algae not in human cell.

The experiment shows that HYDIN colocalizes in the CP cilium of Chlamydomonas.  As human nodal cilium lacks CP,  PCD5 patients do not have situs inversus. PCD5 patients show other manifestations related to defective ciliary structure and/ or motility.
evidence.rdfs:label: Hydin localizes to the CP.

evidence.dc:description: A detailed analysis of the CP apparatus by electron microscopic tomography identified the absence of the C2b projection in HYDIN-mutant cilia from individual OP- 305 II1 (carrying the homozyous splice variant) compared to control samples. Also, image averages  based on six affected and six control TEM images aid visualization of the CP appendages and revealed missing C2b projection
evidence.rdfs:label: Electron microscopy tomography of HYDIN mutant cell

evidence.dc:description: An aberrant flagellar beating pattern with a reduced bending capacity demonstrate dysfunctional sperm in PCD patients. However, it doesn't necessarily indicate HYDIN gene involvement.

HSVM analysis of the patient ejaculate revealed markedly decreased sperm motility, 69% of sperms were completely immotile, and 23% of sperms exhibited only some residual motility. Only 8% of sperms showed some degree of progressive motility. Analysis of these sperm tails revealed an aberrant flagellar beating pattern with a markedly reduced bending capacity, especially of the proximal part of the flagellum. Like respiratory cilia, the HYDIN mutant sperm tails appeared rigid.
evidence.rdfs:label: Functional analysis of sperm tail movement

evidence.dc:description: Dyskinetic cilia of the patient respiratory epithelial cells indicates defective mucociliay clearance which supports PCD diagnosis. However, the evidence is not HYDIN gene specific.

High speed video microscopy (HSVM) analysis of nasal brushings showed motile dyskinetic cilia with uncoordinated and stiff motility. An additional observation of rotational ciliary movement was observed in elder sibling carrying the same homozygous HYDIN mutation.
evidence.rdfs:label: High speed video microscopy analysis of patient cells

evidence.dc:description: Alteration of respiratory cilia motility indicates defective ciliary structure and/or function that might be caused by mutations in other PCD genes and also gives the phenotype.

High-speed video-microscopic evaluation of patients' respiratory cilia beating was able to recognize  abnormalities of the beating pattern. Respiratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity, and the fact that individual cilia exhibited a reduced bending capacity along the ciliary axoneme resulted in reduced beating amplitudes. In comparison to control cilia, they appeared to be more rigid. As a consequence, mutant cilia did not generate distinct effective or recovery strokes and had a reduced capacity to transport mucus or particles . The ciliary beat frequency was normal  in most of the areas analyzed. However, immotile cilia were also found in a few regions. Consistent with the occasional defects of ciliary transposition (indicated by 9+0 and 8+1 axonemes) present in some cross-sections documented by electron microscopy, some ciliary bundles also showed rotatory movement.
evidence.rdfs:label: Functional analysis of respiratory ciliary beating

evidence.dc:description: The paper continued previous work by Davy and Robinson, 2003 where Two mutant alleles of Hydin (hy3 and OVE459) have been characterized with no transcripts have been detected. Both structural and functional defects in the brain and tracheal cells of HYDIN mutant mice. Phenotypes and (non phenotype) matches their human counterparts. PMID  23022101 explained the occurrence of hydrocephalus in HYDIN mutant mice by the fact that integrity of the cilia motility of ependymal cells is mandatory for maintaining patency of the aqueduct of Sylvii, which connects the third and fourth brain ventricles. Thus, disruption of ependymal flow regularly causes hydrocephalus in mice. In contrast, human PCD-affected individuals carry only an increased risk of developing hydrocephalus. Therefore, hydrocephalus in mice remains a supportive evidence of defective ciliary structure and/ or function.

The paper provides evidence on lack of central pair projection and abnormal ciliary bending in HYDIN mutant mice. Both defects are observed in humans and are responsible for inefficient mucociliary clearance observed in PCD patients. Moreover, hy3/hy3 mice, situs abnormalities, as judged by the analysis of lung lobation as well as liver and stomach position in several dozen animals, were not observed which is also consistent with Ciliary dyskinesia, primary, 5(without situs inversus).
evidence.rdfs:label: Mutations in Hydin impair ciliary motility in mice

evidence.dc:description: The model organism carrying HYDIN mutations was further investigated in PMID: 18250199. Given the evident structural and functional alteration revealed, the model has been scored.

While congenital hydrocephalus is lethal and occurs early, and, thus, might have masked other possible phenotypes in HYDIN mutant mice, other phenotypes related to HYDIN tissue expression and defective ciliary function are evident in human patients.
evidence.rdfs:label: Congenital hydrocephalus in HYDIN mutant mice

evidence.dc:description: Downscoring for non applicability of the model to match clinical phenotypes

C. reinhardtii hydin is a CP protein required for flagellar motility and HYDIN knockdown causes flagellar paralysis and absent c2b projection. Similar human phenotypes have been subsequently identified in PMID  23022101. HYDIN mutant respiratory cilia lack the C2b projection of the central pair (CP) apparatus, markedly reduced beating amplitudes of respiratory cilia and stiff sperm flagella could be also identified.
evidence.rdfs:label: Structural and functional role of Chlamydomonas hydin

evidence.dc:description:
A locus was mapped in seven families from the Faroe
Islands to a 2.8 cM interval on chromosome 16p12.1-
12.2, with a maximum lod score of 3.15. We Scored three of these families according to further investigation by WES and sanger sequencing that lead to variant identification in PMID 23022101. In addition, proband of one of these seven families studied has situs inversus which is not considered a phenotype of PCD caused by a central apparatus defect.
evidence.rdfs:label: UCL96, UCL97, UCL98, UCL109, UCL135, UCL139, UCL140

family.rdfs:label: UCL96, UCL97, UCL98, UCL109, UCL135, UCL139, UCL140

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The diagnosis of affected subjects was made according to established clinical criteria supported by abnormal ciliary motility studies and electron microscopy of brushings or biopsy of nasal mucosa. One proband in the family UCL140 exhibited situs inversus.

evidence.rdfs:label: UCL96, UCL109, and UCL139

member.rdfs:label: UCL 109 II1
member.phenotypeFreeText: Respi- ratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity, and the fact that individual cilia exhibited a reduced bending capacity along the ciliary axoneme resulted in reduced beating amplitudes. In comparison to control cilia, they appeared to be more rigid. As a consequence, mutant cilia did not generate distinct effective or recovery strokes and had a reduced capacity to transport mucus or particle.
member.previousTestingDescription: Genome wide linkage scans and subsequent fine mapping

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Chronic nasal discharge since early infancy, chronic rhinosinusitis, Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, except UCL109 II4 who is the only affected person who did not present with neonatal respiratory-distress syndrome but shows other symptoms typical for PCD.
HSVM analysis of nasal-brushing biopsy in individuals UCL139 II1 and UCL109 II1 revealed that respiratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity.

evidence.dc:description: There is no 3 affecteds in the pedigree.
evidence.rdfs:label: GC19277

member.rdfs:label: GC19277 IV-3
member.phenotypeFreeText: Respiratory failure from an early age, Electron microscopy of nasal epithelial cells of the individual  confirmed the absence of the C2b projection of the motile cilia

evidence.dc:description: Not enough affected family members to calculate LOD score (<3).
evidence.rdfs:label: Benjamin_2019
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Early onset persistent wet cough and purulent nasal discharge, occasional crackles on chest examination, motile dyskinetic cilia with uncoordinated and stiff motility on HSVM analysis of nasal brushings.

evidence.dc:description: The family has been included in a previous study where LOD score has been published
evidence.rdfs:label: UCL139

member.rdfs:label: UCL139 II1
member.phenotypeFreeText: Respiratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity, and the fact that individual cilia exhibited a reduced bending capacity along the ciliary axoneme resulted in reduced beating amplitudes. In comparison to control cilia, they appeared to be more rigid. As a consequence, mutant cilia did not generate distinct effective or recovery strokes and had a reduced capacity to transport mucus or particles.
member.previousTestingDescription: Genome wide linkage scans and subsequent fine mapping

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The only affected member of family UCL139, is a 25-year-old person diagnosed at the age of 8 years (UCL139II1).

evidence.dc:description: Not enough affecteds to calculate LOD score
evidence.rdfs:label: UCL 96

evidence.dc:description: Downscoring for homozygosity and consanguinity. upscoring for supportive functional information by RT-PCR. Allele frequency is 0.00001780 in gnomad and the variant is identified in Clinvar as pathogenic.
RT-PCR analysis of RNA extracted from blood samples of the individual  revealed that the variant leads to aberrant pre-mRNA splicing

evidence.rdfs:label: UCL 109 II3
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: chest X-rays showed chronic abnormalities of the right middle lobes
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Genome wide linkage scans and subsequent fine mapping from seven Faroes families revealed a locus mapped to a 2.8 cM interval on chromosome 16p12.1-12.2, with a maximum lod score of 3.15

evidence.dc:description: We scored the proband 109 II1 carrying the same variant in homozygous state.

The variant in exon 8 of HYDIN is predicted to create nonsense alteration p.Lys307*. RT-PCR analysis verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16. All transcripts from the affected person showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*].

Downscoring for homozygosity and consanguinity, upscoring for supportive functional information and RT-PCR analysis. The two affected siblings of the proband 305 II2 and 305 II3 are also homozygous for the variant. The variant identified in Clinvar as (pathogenic).

HYDIN-specific RT-PCR analysis on individual OP-305 II1 has identified abnormal transcripts resulting from malfunction of the HYDIN exon 27 splice acceptor site. The transcripts show a T nucleotide at c.3985  at the first base of exon 27, and contained between the exon 26 and exon 27. Compared to the normal exon 27, The aberrant insertion can be explained by utilization of an upstream cryptic IVS26 splice acceptor.

The variant in exon 8 of HYDIN  is predicted to create nonsense alteration p.Lys307*. WES detected the same mutation in 2 siblings of the proband in addition to 3 patients of 2 affected Faroe families with consistent segregation. The variant is also reported in OP-1808 in PMID  31545650 with consistent phenotype. The variant is asserted "pathogenic"in Clinvar .
Downscoring for homozygosity, upscoring for supportive functional information revealed by RT-PCR.

RT-PCR analysis  verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16. All transcripts from the affected person showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*].
We scored the family Proband 305 II1, homozygous for the same variant, and added the published LOD score for the family as an evidence of disease segregation.

Respiratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity, and exhibited a reduced bending capacity along the ciliary axoneme. These resulted in reduced beating amplitudes. Compared to control cilia, they appeared to be more rigid. 
High-speed videomicroscopic sperm analysis indicates sperm motility was markedly decreased—69% of sperms were completely immotile, and 23% of sperms exhibited only some residual motility. Only 8% of sperms showed some degree of progressive motility. Analysis of these sperm tails revealed an aberrant flagellar beating pattern with a markedly reduced bending capacity, especially of the proximal part of the flagellum. Like respiratory cilia, the HYDIN mutant sperm tails appeared rigid.

evidence.rdfs:label: UCL96II2
evidence.detectionMethod: Segregation-analysis genotypes confirmed that the nonsense variant cosegregates with disease status, which is inherited homozygously in all six affected children of the affected families studied (UCL109, UCL96, UCL139).

evidence.dc:description: We scored the Faroe family 109 with three affected siblings carrying the same variant in homozygous state.

RT-PCR analysis of individual UCL109 II4 and control samples verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16. All transcripts from the affected person  showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*];

evidence.rdfs:label: OI-67 II1
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted next- generation sequencing of a customized PCD gene panel for 42 published genes followed by whole exome sequencing covering HYDIN exons. Mutation was further confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is a frameshift results in more than 80 % of the protein truncated. The variant was also reported in one PCD patient  in PMID  31116566 where quantitative HSVM analysis strategy was applied to build a quantitative “barcode” that discriminates between DNAH11 and HYDIN variants. Downscoring for homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: UCL 109 II4
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Chronic nasal discharge from early infancy, chronic rhinosinusitis
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Genome wide linkage scans and subsequent fine mapping

evidence.dc:description: LOD score for the family 109 was used as a segregation evidence. Proband 109 II1 was also scored.

RT-PCR analysis verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16 with all transcripts from the proband showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*].

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-3022 II2
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted next- generation sequencing of a customized PCD gene panel for 42 published genes (including HYDIN) followed by Whole-exome sequencing covering SPEF2 and HYDIN exon. The identified mutations were further confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: A Nonsense variant results in more than 50% of the protein truncated. The results of the segregation analyses fit perfectly with a homozygous loss-of-function mutation in HYDIN. IF Immunoflurosence and Western blot analysis of SPEF2 (CP-associated protein) reveals its absence from axonemes of HYDIN mutant cells (Figures 5 and 7 respectively). Phenotype is consistent with PCD caused by CP defect. Downscoring for homozygosity.
The older sibling with the nonsense variant in homozygous state was scored.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family_138 patient_46
evidence.detectionMethod: Because of the presence of a pseudogene on chromosome 1 (HYDIN2), further characterization of the variant was conducted using Sanger sequencing.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Clinical genetic testing conducted on 12 genes, mutations that have been implicated in PCD. DNA was extracted and analyzed from peripheral blood. Bidirectional Sanger Sequencing was conducted interrogating all coding exons of each gene, plus 50 base pairs of flanking noncoding DNA on either side of each exon.

evidence.dc:description: Variant is a frameshift predicted to truncate ~70% of the protein and has a gnomAD frequency of 0.00001018. Downscoring for homozygosity and absence of functional supportive information, upscoring for consistency of the phenotype.

evidence.rdfs:label: OP-2108 II1
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted next- generation sequencing of a customized PCD gene panel for 42 published genes followed by whole exome sequencing covering HYDIN exons. Mutation was further confirmed by Sanger sequencing.

evidence.dc:description: The variant is a frameshift in exon 6 results in more than ~96% of the protein truncated. Immunoflurescence of SPEF2 (CP associated protein) reveals its absence in HYDIN mutant cells (Figure5). Reported gnomad frequency is 0.0000077. The father of individual OP-2108 II1 carries only the mutation c.590delG, whereas the mother carries solely the mutation c.1036711G>A. Thus, the results of this segregation analysis are consistent with compound heterozygous HYDIN mutations in the affected individual OP-2108 II1. Downscoring for lack of other functional data.

A splice site variant in exon 61. Immunoflurescence of SPEF2 (CP associated protein) reveals SPEF2 absence in HYDIN mutant cells (Figure5). Segregation analysis evidence supports compound heterozygosity. Downscoring for lack of other functional data.

A splice site variant in exon 27. IF analyses using antibodies directed against SPEF2 revealed its absence from ciliary axonemes of the mutant cells in contrast to control cells. Downscoring for homozygosity.

evidence.rdfs:label: Benjamin_2019 Proband
evidence.detectionMethod: Targeted NGS of 38 genes known to be associated with PCD revealed the nonsense mutation followed by sanger sequencing confirming the result.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Early onset persistent wet cough and purulent nasal discharge, occasional crackles on chest examination, motile dyskinetic cilia with uncoordinated and stiff motility on HSVM analysis of nasal brushings with rotational ciliary movement. An additional observation of rotational ciliary movement was also observed.

evidence.dc:description: Downscoring for homozygosity, consanguinity, absence of functional data and non applicability of measuring nNO.
We scored the Faroe family 109 with three affected siblings carrying the same variant in homozygous state.

RT-PCR analysis of individual UCL109 II4 and control samples verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16. All transcripts from the affected person showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*]
We scored the Faroe family 109 with three affected siblings carrying the same variant in homozygous state.

RT-PCR analysis of individual UCL109 II4 and control samples verified that the c.922A>T nonsense variant is contained within HYDIN on chromosome 16. All transcripts from the affected person showed the homozygous nonsense mutation (c.919A>T [p.Lys307*]
We scored the family Proband 305 II1, homozygous for the same variant, and added the published LOD score for the family as an evidence of disease segregation.

Respiratory cilia lacked coordinated beating activity, and exhibited a reduced bending capacity along the ciliary axoneme. These resulted in reduced beating amplitudes. Compared to control cilia, they appeared to be more rigid.
